results.title: Perdita Durango
results.creator_credit: Alejandro de le Iglesia, Andres Gomes, Canal+ Espana, European Script Fund, Mirador Films, Sogetel and Lolafilms
results.brief_description: The titular protagonist of “Perdita Durango” originated in the David Lynch film “Wild at heart”, as a character played by Isabella Rossellini. In this film Perdita (Rosie Perez) hooks up with Romeo Dolorosa (Javier Bardem) and the two cross the border into Mexico, embarking on a spree of violence, rape and murder. Romeo believes he is protected by unearthly forces and engages in voodoo rituals in order to appease the Gods and maintain his power. After robbing a bank, and crossing an old partner, Romeo agrees to steal a truck full of human foetuses for Santos, a paedophile and crime boss, who is to use them for cosmetic experiments. Romeo and Perdita decide to kidnap two gringos in order to kill, sexually abuse and eat them. A surrealistic action packed film, “Perdito Durango” dabbles in the dark arts as a backdrop to a violent spree of bloodshed and mayhem. Some scenes may disturb viewers.

results.title: What's up Tiger Lily?
results.creator_credit: Woody Allen, Castle Hill and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: A self-reflexive spy spoof, “What’s up Tiger Lily?” marked Woody Allen’s feature debut. Here Allen takes an original Japanese film entitled “Kagi no kagi” and replaces the dialogue with dubbed English to create a comic send-up of a James Bond style crime solving flick. Phil Moskowitz, a loveable rogue is on a deadly mission to prevent a winning recipe for egg-salad from falling into the wrong hands. With the help of some beautiful aides, Moskowitz must foil the plans of the evil Shepherd Wong. The film features a bevy of Japanese beauties and falls into predictable notions of gender and genre. Allen followed up this film with other slapstick comedies such as “Bananas” and “Take the money and run” at the start of a prolific and successful career as a writer/director/actor.

results.title: The Seventh veil
results.creator_credit: Compton Bennett, Sydney Box, Theatrecraft and Ortus Films
results.brief_description: After a car accident Francesca Cunningham (Ann Todd), a gifted pianist, falls into a comatose state, which baffles her doctors. An intuitive psychiatrist puts her under hypnosis in order to unravel the origins of her mental torment and heal her trauma. Under hypnosis (and henceforth told in flashback), Cunningham regales the doctor with tales of her tumultuous past: caning at school, death of her parents, and being made the ward of her very wealthy but emotionally crippled second cousin Nicholas (James Mason). Nicholas recognised in her a unique talent for the piano and committed Francesca to years of relentless study in order for her to become a professional classical musician. Even as an adult Nicholas still wields enormous emotional power over Francesca, preventing her from realising true personal happiness. “The Seventh veil” is an intense psychodrama, which uses gothic sets and expressionistic lighting to convey a grave sense of mental torture for its principal characters. Winner of an Academy award for best original screenplay in 1947, this film was a box-office success in Britain.

results.title: Thirteen days = Thirteen days that shocked the world
results.creator_credit: Roger Donaldson, Mary Montiforte, Paul Deacon, Kevin Costner, Armyan Bernstein, Peter O Almond and Beacon Communications, Tig Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the book “The Kennedy Tapes - inside the White House During the Cuban Missile Crisis” by Ernest R. May and Philip D. Zelikow, “Thirteen Days” is a riveting drama about one of the most significant moments in the Cold War. Set almost entirely in the White House the film examines President John Kennedy’s (Bruce Greenwood) role in the Crisis, his relationship with his brother Robert (Steven Culp) - the then Attorney General of the USA - and the crucial role played by the President’s political advisor, Kenny O’Donnell (Kevin Costner). Simply but elegantly shot by Andrzej Bartkowiak and featuring a well-researched and structured screenplay by David Self, the film approaches a near-documentary realism. Roger Donaldson’s taut direction builds a consistent tension without sacrificing the complexities of the historical drama. Undoubtedly the closest the world has come to a nuclear war, the film establishes the diplomatic and military stand-off between the USA and the USSR as the key foreign affairs event for both President Kennedy and for Soviet leader Kruschev. This film is an excellent political thriller, its impact made more chillingly frightening by our knowledge of the catastrophic consequences of one wrong, or ill-communicated, political decision.

results.title: Drop dead gorgeous
results.creator_credit: Michael Patrick Jann, Judy Hofflund, Gavin Polone, New Line Cinema, KC Medien and Capella
results.brief_description: Set in small town America, “Drop dead gorgeous” is a satire about teen beauty contests, ambitious parents and urban dysfunction. As the citizens of Mount Rose, Minnesota gear up for the Sarah Rose Miss Teen Princess America Pageant, the proceedings are filmed by a documentary crew, lending the film its mockumentary structure. The main contestants are Becky Leeman, whose ambitious mother runs the beauty contest and Amber Atkins, a plucky and talented working class teen who lives in a trailer park with her depressed alcoholic mother. When various contestants die in an array of mysterious circumstances Amber suspects that her life is in danger if she stays in competition. This film takes a savage view of American societal mores, as it mocks small town values, beauty contests, marriage, alcoholism, obesity, anorexia, paedophiles, handicapped people, mother-daughter relationships and the gauche self-consciousness of teenagers. It gladly follows in the footsteps of “Waiting for Guffman” and “Spinal tap”, but never reaches the hilarity of such predecessors, possibly due to its good natured and loveable heroine, contrasting too starkly with hideous caricatures. At times the black humour and merciless ridiculing of the screenplay are uncomfortable to watch, defiantly crossing over into bad taste on numerous occasions.

results.title: Odd man out
results.creator_credit: Fergus McDonell, Carol Reed and Two Cities Films
results.brief_description: James Mason is a wounded IRA gunman staggering through the streets of Belfast from one refuge to the next as his life ebbs away. The realism of the early scenes of robbery and escape merges into nightmarish images of the darkened city and then spills over into the baroque excess of the hallucinating man on the run’s encounter with a drunken artist. The central character is essentially passive; the dramatic emphasis is on the reactions of those around him. Directed by Carol Reed (The Third man).

results.title: The League of gentlemen
results.creator_credit: Basil Dearden, Michael Relph and Allied Filmmakers
results.brief_description: A disgruntled army colonel who has been forcibly retired decides to take revenge on England by executing a daring daylight bank robbery. To undertake the crime he commandeers seven ex-army men who have fallen foul of the law in some way or other. The eight men (who don’t know each other) treat the assignment like a reconnaissance mission, carefully planned under the leadership of Colonel Hyde. “The League of gentlemen” is an old-fashioned caper movie that moves exceptionally well through the stages of the crime: the initial research, the preparations, the raid for ammunition, the day of the heist, the aftermath. The film also serves as a timepiece for England in the late 1950s - the last dregs of post-war hang-ups, the loosening of morals and hints of the swinging 60s, the displacement of these men who have moved from the heroism of their war years to shady existences. Adapted from the novel by John Boland, “The League of Gentlemen” has a pacey and witty script that is buoyed by fine performances from Jack Hawkins, Nigel Patrick, Roger Livesey and Richard Attenborough.

results.title: Dancehall queen [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Rick Elgood, Don Letts, Carl Bradshaw, Carolyn Pfeiffer, Hawk's Nest Productions and Island Jamaica Films
results.brief_description: Filmed on location in Kingston, Jamaica, “Dancehall Queen”s’ plot centres on the travails of Marcia, a struggling single mother who works as a street vendor to support her two daughters. Threatened by a benefactor who demands sexual favours from her teenage daughter, and a thug intent on destroying her vending business, she enters a dance hall contest and regains control of her life. The highlight of the film is the depiction of Jamaica’s vibrant dancehall culture. The dancehall, which historically provided a vital space for the development of reggae music, continues to be one of Jamaica’s most energized environments, bubbling with a creativity expressed through outrageous fashions, defiant sexual expression, innovative dance steps, a distinct vernacular and, of course, its ever evolving music. Dancehall music is the present day form of Jamaican reggae, voicing the young (and the not so young) population’s concerns, conflicts, fantasies and frustrations, while offering escapist, humorous observations of oppressive situations. While dancehall music is dominated by men, the dancing is ruled by women who compete with each other to come up with the most risque costumes—characterised by excessive amounts of jewelry, pastel-colored wigs and thigh-high patent leather boots—and the most sexually provocative dance moves. Though the Jamaican Patois English is sometimes hard to decipher, “Dancehall Queen” offers a vibrant portrayal of contemporary Jamaica. Includes music from Beenie Man, Chevelle Franklyn, Bounty Killer, The Marley Girls and Grace Jones.

results.title: Hearts in Atlantis
results.creator_credit: Scott Hicks, Kerry Heysen, Village Roadshow Pictures, NPV Entertainment and Castle Rock Entertainment
results.brief_description: A nostalgic film set in small town America of the 1960s about maturation and the loss of innocence. Bobby is an eleven-year-old boy feeling the stigma of being from a financially strapped one-parent family. One summer a mysterious boarder Ted Brautigan (Anthony Hopkins) comes to live in the upstairs part of the house and wins over Bobby, if not his suspicious mother, Liz. It is gradually revealed that Ted has psychic powers and sinister men in dark suits are pursuing him. Bobby, in need of a father figure, is drawn into Ted’s confidence, working for him, and absorbing Ted’s wisdom. Ted assists Bobby with difficult life matters - his first kiss, trust in others, and lessons in disappointment. Structured as a flashback, “Hearts in Atlantis” has a tone not unlike a darkly themed episode of “The Wonder years.” Hicks peppers a pedestrian screenplay, laden with symbolic diatribes, with 60s hits, an expressive score, and an eye for period detail. Hope Davis puts in an understated performance as Liz - a woman who struggles with her financial situation, whilst fending off her lecherous boss. Directed by Scott Hicks (Shine, Snow falling on cedars).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Scott Hicks, Kerry Heysen, Village Roadshow Pictures, NPV Entertainment and Castle Rock Entertainment
results.description: A nostalgic film set in small town America of the 1960s about maturation and the loss of innocence. Bobby is an eleven-year-old boy feeling the stigma of being from a financially strapped one-parent family. One summer a mysterious boarder Ted Brautigan (Anthony Hopkins) comes to live in the upstairs part of the house and wins over Bobby, if not his suspicious mother, Liz. It is gradually revealed that Ted has psychic powers and sinister men in dark suits are pursuing him. Bobby, in need of a father figure, is drawn into Ted’s confidence, working for him, and absorbing Ted’s wisdom. Ted assists Bobby with difficult life matters - his first kiss, trust in others, and lessons in disappointment. Structured as a flashback, “Hearts in Atlantis” has a tone not unlike a darkly themed episode of “The Wonder years.” Hicks peppers a pedestrian screenplay, laden with symbolic diatribes, with 60s hits, an expressive score, and an eye for period detail. Hope Davis puts in an understated performance as Liz - a woman who struggles with her financial situation, whilst fending off her lecherous boss. Directed by Scott Hicks (Shine, Snow falling on cedars).

results.title: Pulp fiction [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Quentin Tarantino, Lawrence Bender, Miramax Films, Jersey Films and A Band Apart
results.brief_description: Tarantino’s amoral black gangster movie pilfers cinematic conventions from a diverse range of sources: from Hong Kong karate cinema to Orson Welles, from Godard’s “Breathless” to B-grade film noir. The mix is intoxicating. Three pulpy stories form the centre of the film. John Travolta plays a mafia hood with a keen addiction to heroin, who is asked to entertain for an evening the girlfriend (Uma Thurman) of his mobster boss; Bruce Willis is an ageing boxer who is asked to throw a fight; and Travolta and Samuel Jackson have to hide the body of a conman they accidentally shot. Surrounding these basic plot contrivances Tarantino creates a charged, constantly shifting narrative that introduces highly eccentric characters drawn from the extremes of popular music, junk and drug culture. The supporting cast is astounding, from Harvey Keitel and Tarantino himself, to Tim Roth and Amanda Plummer’s surreal performance as amphetamine-hyped killers. By introducing peripheral subcultures to the Hollywood mainstream, Tarantino’s film marked a generational shift in American movies. Not the Vietnam generation but the video generation. (Awards: Winner of Palme d’Or, Cannes, 1994).
